Stock futures surged ahead of Friday's open with tech stocks hoisted by positive earnings results and futures tracking a moderate late-week rally in Europe. Dow futures traded 75 points higher and were on the rise. Nasdaq 100 futures, also rising, were up 14.5 points and S&P 500 futures climbed 8.5 points. Despite the early optimism, the stock market today faces…
Stocks remained in the red at midafternoon Monday, though the Dow Jones industrial average held its loss to 0.2%.
The S&P 500 shed 0.5%, while the Nasdaq fared worst with a 0.9% decline. Volume was tracking down slightly from Thursday's level for the NYSE. It was up a little for the Nasdaq.
The stock market today has taken a step back after disappointing manufacturing data. The Institute for Supply Management said its manufacturing index declined more than expected in March to 51.3.

Among IBD 50 stocks, NeuStar (NSR) slid 3% in strong volume, putting the telecom stock back near its 50-day moving average. NeuStar, which holds a big government contract tied to phone number portability, could be getting hit by a Bloomberg report today saying Vonage and other voice-over-Internet providers are asking the FCC for direct access to unused phone numbers. It's No. 48 in Monday's IBD 50.
HomeAway (AWAY) was also down 3% in active turnover. The online provider of vacation rentals, No. 6 in the IBD 50, remains well-extended beyond its last proper buying range.

On the upside, Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR) rose 1% in above-average volume. The maker of single-cup brewers is No. 1 in the IBD 50, but it's not in a buy zone and still has overhead supply to work through.

EBay (EBAY) jumped 3% in strong turnover. The online auctions pioneer has gotten a lift today from several bullish analyst notes. It has climbed back above its 50-day line as it continues to work on a flat base. The stock stands about 2% off a high hit in February. Stocks continued to hold near their best levels of the session late Thursday. Most of the major stock indexes were on pace for a fifth straight gain.

The Nasdaq climbed 0.8% and the S&P 500 rose 0.7%. Both were looking at their fifth straight up day. The Dow Jones industrial average added 0.4%. Turnover was tracking higher on both major exchanges in the stock market today.

Cabela's (CAB) was off its session high, but still up 14% after blowing past views. Before the open, the outdoor equipment retailer delivered Q1 earnings that jumped 75% to 70 cents a share. It beat by 11 cents. Thanks to strong demand for guns and ammo, sales rose 29% to $802.5 million. Both top- and bottom-line growth were the best in years. The stock cleared a 62.32 buy point from an irregular flat base.

PulteGroup (PHM) bolted 6% despite reporting mixed Q1 results earlier Thursday. The stock is in a double-bottom base with a 21.70 buy point. But the pattern is a third-stage base. Generally, first- or second-stage patterns are preferred.

Overstock.com (OSTK) reversed early losses and gained 5% to its best levels in almost three years. It's now 17% past a 17.75 buy point from a cup base cleared April 19. Overstock's base corrected 39%, which is deep. Last week, the online retailer delivered Q1 results well ahead of expectations.

Proto Labs (PRLB) shaved an earlier 8% loss to about 2%. It also climbed back above its 50-day moving average. The maker of custom parts sold off as a warning about its profit margin offset better-than-expected Q1 results. Proto Labs recently had a failed breakout, but it found support near the 45 level.

Investors will look to see whether Health Management Associates (HMA) and LifePoint Hospitals (LPNT) have found a prescription for profits as they announce fourth-quarter results this week.
Both hospital companies have seen profits fall and are forecast to report lower earnings per share amid rising commodity costs and other expenses.
Still, shares of both are trading near 52-week highs and well above 50-day and 200-day averages.
Health Management, whose shares hit an 18-month high Friday, will report Thursday after the market closes.
The consensus of 10 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters is for Q4 EPS to fall 31% to 18 cents and for revenue to climb 6.3% to $1.68 billion.

The hospital operator last Wednesday announced a definitive agreement to buy an 80% controlling interest in Bayfront Health System in St. Petersburg, Fla. After the transaction concludes, Health Management will operate a total 71 hospitals with about 11,000 beds throughout the U.S.
Since Dec. 19, share price has surged about 43%. It boasts a near-best 98 IBD Composite Rating, meaning it's outperformed 98% of all stocks on key metrics such as sales and profit growth.
Health Management was down about 1.1% in Monday afternoon trading on the stock market today.
LifePoint Hospitals, a spinoff of hospital giant HCA Holdings (HCA), is slated to report Friday before the market opens.
HCA, along with biotech Celgene (CELG) and medical equipment maker ResMed (RMD), hit a 52-week high the first week of February. HCA has faded a bit since then.
The outlook for LifePoint is for EPS to fall 17% to 65 cents, and revenue to slide 6% to $861.7 million
LifePoint could be impacted this year by a section of the Affordable Care Act, or ObamaCare, that penalize hospitals with high rates of readmissions for Medicare patients.
Because of its high exposure to Medicare, LifePoint could face penalties this year in the form of lower Medicare reimbursements, according to the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Services, or CMS.

Last Thursday, LifePoint named a new chief medical officer, Russell Holman, replacing Lanny Copeland, who retired. Holman stepped into the post Monday, although Copeland will assist during a transition period.
Like Health Management, LifePoint consolidated for most of 2012.
LifePoint slid 0.7% in Monday afternoon trading, but was about 28% higher than an intraday low of 34.37 on Oct. 31.

Elsewhere in the Medical-Hospitals group, ranked a lofty No. 3 on IBD's list of 197 industry groups, HCA and Universal Health Services (UHS) were down more than 1.3% and Tenet Healthcare (THC) declined 0.8%.Investors will look to see whether Health Management Associates (HMA) and LifePoint Hospitals (LPNT) have found a prescription for profits as they announce fourth-quarter results this week.Both hospital companies have seen profits fall and are forecast to report lower earnings per share amid rising commodity costs and other expenses.Still, shares of both are trading near 52-week highs and well above 50-day and 200-day averages.Health Management, whose shares hit an 18-month high Friday, will report Thursday after the market closes.The consensus of 10 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters is for Q4 EPS to fall 31% to 18 cents and for revenue to climb 6.3% to $1.68 billion.The hospital operator last Wednesday announced a definitive agreement to buy an 80% controlling interest in Bayfront Health System in St. Petersburg, Fla. After the transaction concludes, Health Management will operate a total 71 hospitals with about 11,000 beds throughout the U.S.Since Dec. 19, share price has surged about 43%. It boasts a near-best 98 IBD Composite Rating, meaning it's outperformed 98% of all stocks on key metrics such as sales and profit growth.Health Management was down about 1.1% in Monday afternoon trading on the stock market today.LifePoint Hospitals, a spinoff of hospital giant HCA Holdings (HCA), is slated to report Friday before the market opens.HCA, along with biotech Celgene (CELG) and medical equipment maker ResMed (RMD), hit a 52-week high the first week of February. HCA has faded a bit since then.The outlook for LifePoint is for EPS to fall 17% to 65 cents, and revenue to slide 6% to $861.7 millionLifePoint could be impacted this year by a section of the Affordable Care Act, or ObamaCare, that penalize hospitals with high rates of readmissions for Medicare patients.Because of its high exposure to Medicare, LifePoint could face penalties this year in the form of lower Medicare reimbursements, according to the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Services, or CMS.Last Thursday, LifePoint named a new chief medical officer, Russell Holman, replacing Lanny Copeland, who retired. Holman stepped into the post Monday, although Copeland will assist during a transition period.Like Health Management, LifePoint consolidated for most of 2012.LifePoint slid 0.7% in Monday afternoon trading, but was about 28% higher than an intraday low of 34.37 on Oct. 31.Elsewhere in the Medical-Hospitals group, ranked a lofty No. 3 on IBD's list of 197 industry groups, HCA and Universal Health Services (UHS) were down more than 1.3% and Tenet Healthcare (THC) declined 0.8%.
When it comes to retirement planning, IRAs are still Americans' main tool.
We had $5.7 trillion tucked away in IRAs as of the end of the second quarter, according to the Investment Company Institute. That dwarfed the $3.8 trillion at work in 401(k) plans.
But harsh tax rules mean that a false step with your IRA can be costly. So here are six tips for making the most of your IRA, both for yourself and your heirs.
 Beneficiary. Many people think of their will as the document with the last say when it comes to their estate. That's not true for your IRA.

For that account, your beneficiary is the person you name in your IRA custodian's designation form. It does not matter who, if anyone, you name in your will. A community property state may require you to designate your spouse, says IRA Advisor editor Ed Slott.
So, if you want to name a beneficiary, use that form. If you want to change your beneficiary, file an amended designation form with your financial firm.

 RMDs. With a traditional IRA, the owner must start required minimum distributions (RMDs) by April 1 of the year after he or she turns 70-1/2. RMDs are based on IRS life expectancy tables. You calculate each year's RMD by dividing the balance as of the prior Dec. 31 by your life expectancy in the IRS table that applies to you.

 Roth IRA. You can avoid having to take RMDs by using a Roth IRA instead of a traditional one, or by converting a traditional IRA to a Roth. With a Roth, no RMDs are required. You can convert a traditional IRA to a Roth. You'll owe income tax on the amount converted, but your eventual withdrawals, if any, will be tax free. That can leave more for your heirs to inherit tax free.

 Rules for heirs. Heirs do not have as good a deal as an original account owner does. After getting the account tax-free, nonspousal heirs must start withdrawals, based on an age-based formula, by Dec. 31 of the year after they inherit the IRA. That's the case whether it's a traditional or Roth IRA.
Younger beneficiaries can take smaller withdrawals, allowing the account balance to keep growing tax-deferred longer.

Some heirs mistakenly think they don't need to take RMDs from an inherited Roth. They do. But there's no tax. "But if they don't make the withdrawal, they're subject to a 50% penalty — far worse than any tax would have been," Slott said.
 Spouses. Spousal heirs can keep an inherited IRA as an inherited IRA or roll it into his or her own name. The terminology matters.

If a spousal heir takes an inherited IRA (traditional or Roth) as a beneficiary, then RMDs must start in the year his or her deceased spouse would have turned 70-1/2. But if she takes a traditional IRA as a rollover, it is treated as if it had always been hers. If she is young, it may be years or even decades before RMDs must start. If it's a Roth, RMDs never start.

Still, a spousal heir younger than 59-1/2 should take it as an inherited IRA in case she needs the money. That way she can dip into the account without paying a 10% penalty for early withdrawal, Slott says.
 Estates. Never name your estate as a beneficiary unless you have no beneficiaries or don't care about their tax burden, Slott says.

RMDs for an estate follow different rules. In many cases the withdrawals must be within a short number of years, resulting in quick depletion of the original account.When it comes to retirement planning, IRAs are still Americans' main tool.We had $5.7 trillion tucked away in IRAs as of the end of the second quarter, according to the Investment Company Institute. That dwarfed the $3.8 trillion at work in 401(k) plans.But harsh tax rules mean that a false step with your IRA can be costly. Stocks kicked off the week with solid gains but disappointing volume once again revealed a lack of conviction behind the buying. The Nasdaq hit a new multiyear high on an intraday basis, ending with a gain of 0.9%. The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 rose 0.7% each. The S&P 500 made a new closing high of 1593.61 but…

Wall Street held on to slim gains late Wednesday, after the Federal Reserve kept to its monetary policy and said the economy was expanding modestly. The Dow Jones industrial average was up 0.3%, the S&P 500 edged up 0.2% and the Nasdaq was up a fraction in a seesaw session. Volume was higher on the Nasdaq but lower on the…

Wall Street remained in the red late Tuesday afternoon following a sell-off sparked by weak outlooks at industrial titans such as 3M (MMM) and Moody's downgrade of debt in several Spanish regions. The Dow Jones industrial average slumped 1.7%, the S&P 500 1.4% and the Nasdaq 0.8%. Volume was tracking higher across the board. Apple (AAPL) was down more than…

Stocks extended their losses late Thursday after search giant Google (GOOG) reported weaker-than-expected quarterly earnings in a surprisingly early announcement. The Nasdaq was down 1.3%, the S&P 500 fell 0.6% and the Dow Jones industrial average was 0.3% lower, erasing earlier gains. Volume was tracking higher across the board. Google plunged 9%, weighing on the Nasdaq, after third-quarter profit and…
Stocks turned lower in weak trade at midday Friday as a weaker-than-expected gain in consumer sentiment outweighed a slight pickup in U.S. economic activity.

The Nasdaq was down 0.2% after rising 0.2% at the open. The S&P 500 also dipped 0.2%, while the Dow Jones industrial average was off 0.1%. Volume was running 10% lower on the Nasdaq and 5% lower on the NYSE compared with the same time Thursday.

Web.com Group (WWWW) plunged 13% in massive volume, slicing through its 50-day and 200-day moving averages. The website publishing service reported after the close Thursday that third-quarter profit rose a better-than-expected 41% from a year ago to 41 cents a share. Web.com's Q3 revenue also beat views, but the stock still dived.

ResMed (RMD), which makes devices to treat sleep-related breathing disorders, fell 4% in huge turnover but managed to get support near its 50-day line. The company late Thursday reported that Q3 profit rose 42% from a year ago to 54 cents a share, beating analysts' forecasts. But revenue was only in line with estimates.

Under Armour (UA), which makes athletic apparel, fell 2% in more than double its average daily volume. The stock has fallen for five straight sessions, sinking below its 50-day line. It's 14% off its Sept. 14 high of 60.96.

On the upside, Comcast (CMCSA) was up 2% in strong turnover, approaching a high of 37.60 set last week. The cable TV service provider is 5% past 35.26 entry point, putting it at the upper end of its buying range. It reported adjusted EPS that matched forecasts, along with revenue that topped estimates.

Also Friday, cloud computing stock NetSuite (N) jumped 13% in huge volume, rebounding above its 50-day line. It got a lift from an upgrade from Northland Securities. The stock is now 9% above a 59.32 flat-base entry after closing below the buy point on Monday.
In economic news, the U.S. economy grew at an annual rate of 2% in Q3, topping the expected 1.9% increase and improving on the prior quarter's 1.3% annual growth rate.

Stocks added ground Friday, with the Dow and the S&P 500 striking their highest levels in five years. But volume backed off. The Nasdaq — recovering from Friday's Apple-induced stumble — rose 0.5%. The S&P 500 climbed 0.4% and the Dow Jones industrial average added 0.3%. Volume declined on both major exchanges, according to preliminary data. Energy and tech stocks…
Stocks were hitting session highs late Thursday, recouping a big chunk of the previous day's losses, amid mixed earnings reports and economic data.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.7%, the Nasdaq rallied 0.6% and the S&P 500 added 0.3%. Volume was tracking higher on the Nasdaq and lower on the NYSE compared to the same time Wednesday.

In the stock market today, NQ Mobile (NQ) plunged as much as 55% in massive volume after short seller Muddy Waters Research Group slapped a "strong sell" rating on the stock, calling the Chinese developer of mobile security software a "massive fraud."
Muddy Waters accused the company of falsifying financial information and vastly overstating its market share in China.
Meanwhile, gunmaker Sturm Ruger (RGR) dropped 5% in volume that was running more than double its daily average.
The stock had recently risen 20% above a 56.98 buy point, a level at which investors should consider taking profits. It's now 13% above the buy point.

Generac Holdings (GNRC) was the biggest gainer among IBD 50 stocks. The maker of portable generators gapped up and bolted 15% after reporting Q3 results that blew away views. The company also raised its full-year sales outlook due to strong demand for its residential generators and impact from its Baldor Generators buyout. Generac cleared a 44.34 buy point from a late-stage double-bottom base.

Elsewhere, Medidata Solutions (MDSO) soared 16% to a new high after the provider of clinical development software reported that Q3 profit jumped 67% from a year earlier, beating Wall Street expectations. Sales for the period rose 27%.

Stocks opened higher, but quickly began to trim gains on Friday, as the dollar edged higher and oil prices held steady. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 added 0.2% apiece. The Nasdaq held on to its 0.5% advance.
Volume was soft, down 14% on the Nasdaq and 90% lower on the NYSE, compared with trade at the same time Thursday.

The stock market today is rebounding, but still correcting, with both the Nasdaq and the S&P 500 deep in the hole for the week. The market received an early assist today from China, where some rule changes and federally engineered buying helped lift markets to their first healthy close of the week.
December hiring in the U.S. was also a factor, as the Labor Department reported payrolls jumped by 292,000 during the month — far above expectations.
Wholesale inventories dropped 0.3% in November, the Commerce Department said. That was even with October's slip and below expectations for no change.

The market will have an ear out for post-payroll comments from San Francisco Federal Reserve Bank President John Williams, who speaks at 11:30 a.m. ET, and from Richmond Federal Reserve Bank President Jeffrey Lacker, on the docket for a 1 p.m. speech.
Apple (AAPL) and DuPont (DD) raced to the head of the Dow, up nearly 2% each. Wynn Resorts (WYNN)headed the S&P 500 with a 4% gain.
Gap (GPS) cratered 7% after announcing late Thursday its December same-store sales slipped 5% vs. consensus views for a 3.5% decline.

Chipmaker and Apple supplier Qorvo (QRVO) dropped 4%. The Greensboro, N.C. company late Thursday lowered its Q3 revenue guidance to well below consensus expectations. The company also said it repurchased $250 million in shares during the quarter, leaving $750 million in its share repurchase program and a cash balance of more than $1 billion. Shares traded down 14% for the week and 50% below a June high.

On the IBD 50 list, Universal Display (OLED) flashed ahead nearly 5% at the open. The maker of organic light emitting diode chips used in high definition TV and computer screens is trading below a 55.93 buy point in a cup base. It triggered an automatic sell signal by diving more than 8% below that mark.

Hawaiian (HA) jumped more than 3% after reporting its total numbers of passengers rose 4.1% and its load factor crept up to 82.9% in the fourth quarter. The stock remains well below its 50-day moving average and is attempting to build the right side of a 22% deep consolidation.

Aircraft carrier mechanic Huntington Ingalls Industries (HII) sailed ahead nearly 4%. Cowen & Co. upgraded the stock to outperform from market perform. Huntington is trading below a 136.55 buy point in a long cup-with-handle base.Stocks opened higher, but quickly began to trim gains on Friday, as the dollar edged higher and oil prices held steady. Three issues in Stocks In The News that managed to do exactly that are ResMed (RMD), 99 Cents Only Stores (NDN) and Tyson Foods (TSN). ResMed broke out of a flat base on Friday, hitting a three-year high. That came after it reported…

July retail sales hint at a strengthening economy. Some analysts believe the worst of the housing crisis is over. The Nasdaq on Friday confirmed a market rally. Now may be the time for investors to look for leading companies breaking out to new highs. Stocks that have done well despite the market correction are normally first to surge when a…

The Nasdaq and S&P 500 made it five gains in a row Wednesday as quiet headline flow gave the bulls more reason to put money to work. Major averages finished near session highs thanks to a flurry of buying late in the session. At the close, the Nasdaq gained 0.5%, the S&P 500 0.4% and the Dow Jones industrial average…

The $1 billion Nuveen Mid Cap Growth Opportunities Fund is notching a nice, though not spectacular, return for shareholders. It has not outperformed both its midcap growth peers and the S&P 500 since the first quarter. But it topped its direct rivals in Q2. It was close in Q3. And its Q1 outperformance was large. So for the whole year…

Created in 1974, IRAs have become a key part of retirement finance for many Americans. The Investment Company Institute reports that 39% of U.S. households headed by someone 65 or older have an IRA. Many 40-, 50- and 60-somethings will inherit those IRAs. After, they'll have to take taxable distributions. To trim the eventual tax hit, offspring can give seniors…

Stocks remained lower in early afternoon trading Monday after New York-area manufacturing activity contracted to its lowest level in almost 3-1/2 years and unrest in the Middle East continued.
The Nasdaq slipped 0.4%, the S&P 500 0.2% and the Dow Jones industrial average 0.3%. Volume tracked 33% lower on the Nasdaq and was off 37% on the NYSE, compared with the same time Friday.
The New York Federal Reserve's Empire State Manufacturing Index slipped 4.5 points to -10.4 in September. Analysts had expected -3.
Some China-based stocks sank on speculation that Beijing may take steps to cool the housing market. China Mobile (CHL) lost 1% in huge volume. NetEase (NTES) slipped 3%, also in heavy turnover.

Medical product makers were having a tough day. Edwards Lifesciences (EW) appeared headed for its sixth straight decline, falling 1% in heavy volume. The maker of heart valves and other devices is below a 107.04 buy point in a flat base.

Meanwhile, ResMed (RMD), which makes treatments for sleep-related breathing disorders, was down more than 1% in strong turnover. It's extended well beyond a 35.23 buy point from a cup-without-handle base.
On the upside, Apple (AAPL) edged up 1%, flirting with the 700 mark, after the company last week unveiled the iPhone 5. The stock is well past a 619.97 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.

Randgold Resources (GOLD) climbed 1% after Citigroup upgraded the stock to neutral from sell. The U.K.-based miner has risen sharply for four straight weeks, including two in heavy volume, amid rising bullion prices.Stocks remained lower in early afternoon trading Monday after New York-area manufacturing activity contracted to its lowest level in almost 3-1/2 years and unrest in the Middle East continued.The Nasdaq slipped 0.4%, the S&P 500 0.2% and the Dow Jones industrial average 0.3%. Volume tracked 33% lower on the Nasdaq and was off 37% on the NYSE, compared with the same time Friday.The New York Federal Reserve's Empire State Manufacturing Index slipped 4.5 points to -10.4 in September. Analysts had expected -3.Some China-based stocks sank on speculation that Beijing may take steps to cool the housing market. China Mobile (CHL) lost 1% in huge volume. NetEase (NTES) slipped 3%, also in heavy turnover.Medical product makers were having a tough day. Edwards Lifesciences (EW) appeared headed for its sixth straight decline, falling 1% in heavy volume. The maker of heart valves and other devices is below a 107.04 buy point in a flat base.Meanwhile, ResMed (RMD), which makes treatments for sleep-related breathing disorders, was down more than 1% in strong turnover. The Q4 earnings season unofficially started earlier this month with aluminum giant Alcoa (AA). This week, dozens of S&P 500 stocks report results, headlined by tech giants Google (GOOG) (Tuesday) and Apple (AAPL) (Wednesday). But beneath the headlines is the real story, at least for savvy traders. Four stocks on the elite IBD 50 are on deck. First up is…

August arrivals upon the IBD 50 present a mixed-bag of companies, with various levels of familiarity with watchers of our top-stocks list.Grand Canyon Education had only been off a very short time, but for Gartner, ResMed and Seagate, it's been much longer, years.Whether the stocks that breezed in on the summer wind will take stick around is impossible to say, but let's take a look at August's arrivals, by their latest IBD 50 ranking:28. ResMed (RMD). The maker of airflow generators and other products to treat sleep apnea and other sleeping disorders rejoined the IBD 50 on Aug. 6. One big reason was the 12% jump in its shares on Aug. 3, after its fiscal Q3 results beat Wall Street expectations. The breathing-device maker has been boosting its profit margins by giving more emphasis on its higher-end products. A new U.S. tax on certain medical devices, set to take effect next year, will impact ResMed. But BMO Capital Markets analyst Joanne Wuensch says executives have assured her the impact will be "minimal," as we recently reported. The stock hit an entry buy point of 35.23 the day of its big 12% jump. It closed Friday at 36.90, so it's less than 5% extended. Founder Peter Farrell left the company in 2007 but returned as CEO in February 2011.29. Grand Canyon Education (LOPE). The company popped back on the IBD 50 this month after being off . .. a week. It was one the Monday IBD 50s for three weeks in July, but that was its first time back in the rankings in a long time. The for-profit educational firm mostly offers online degree courses, though it also runs a traditional campus in Phoenix. The campus has sports teams called the Antelopes, which accounts for the LOPE stock ticker. New laws designed to cut down on student loan defaults at for-profit schools have not hurt the company as much as originally feared, analysts recently told IBD. "Grand Canyon is well above the compliance thresholds," said Jerry Herman, analyst with Stifel Nicolaus. The company emphasizes what some consider practical fields, such nursing and business, that prepare students for the real workforce. The stock jumped 20% on Aug. 7 after it raised its full-year guidance.41. Gartner (IT). Tech research firm Gartner returned, after a long absence, to the IBD 50 with a heady No. 38 ranking on Aug. 13, and now checks in No. 41. The stock last month hit a 44.34 buy point out of a cup-with-handle base. It closed Friday at 48.76, so it's nearly 10% extended, a bit further than optimum. The stock rose more than 5% on Aug. 3, to an all-time high for the 33-year-old company, after earnings beat views and it maintained its guidance. And the stock is up slightly since then. Since the start of 2010, Gartner's quarterly year-over-year EPS growth has been at least 14%, with sales rising 9% to 17%. It's performed better than other publicly traded tech research firms Forrester Research (FORR) and ComScore (SCOR). Gartner has an IBD Composite Rating — our broadest measure of performance over the past 12 months — of 97, putting it among the top 3% of all stocks. It claims clients in 85 countries, and is well-known by business journalists, including IBD. In fact, Gartner says its analysts are quoted in the business press an average of 70 times a week.47. Seagate Technology (STX). It's been years, but disk drive maker Seagate Technology, one of tech's longtimers, returned to the IBD 50 list of Aug. 13. It did fall off our Aug. 15 rankings, but is back on with the latest list, at No. 47. The stock broke out of a 13-week base and hit a 32.65 buy point on Tuesday. It closed Friday at 35.67, up 3%, and that's a nearly 12-year high. This is so even though the company lowered its guidance on July 30. But Seagate and archrival Western Digital (WDC) are rebounding from the terrible flooding in Thailand last year that wiped out much of their production operations. Western Digital's good results in late July boosted both it and Seagate, as we reported. The 26-year-old company has seen a ton of ebb and flow in its industry, as its chief financial officer, Patrick O'Malley, told IBD in June: "When I started in 1988 at Seagate, there were 92 disk drive companies. Now we are down to three — Western Digital, Seagate and Toshiba (but) the competition remains intense."Follow Mike Krey on Twitter

Stocks wavered to an essentially flat finish Wednesday amid disappointing data on durable goods orders and a flood of earnings reports. The Nasdaq rose a fraction, while the S&P 500 rose a tick. The 30-stock Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.3%. Losses in Procter & Gamble (PG) and Cisco Systems (CSCO) weighed on the blue-chip index. According to preliminary data, volume…

Things went from bad to worse ahead of Thursday's open, as disappointing jobless claims data compounded a global sell-off, sending futures sharply lower. Dow futures were down more than 100 points and still falling. Nasdaq 100 futures were down 25.25 points, and S&P 500 futures dimmed 14.25 points. The stock market today may offer clues as to the strength of…

A number of IBD 50 stocks have pulled back as the market's uptrend shows some signs of fatigue. But many are getting support at or above their 10-week lines, and a few are still marching to new highs. Web.com Group (WWWW) jumped past an 18.40 entry from a cup-with-handle base on Tuesday before sinking 4% Wednesday in heavy volume. The…

The major averages, after erasing early gains, headed into the close little changed. But several leading stocks on the IBD 50 list sold off in the wake of poorly received earnings reports. That's a bad sign for the general market. Sherwin-Williams (SHW), paint maker and retailer, just edged past earnings forecasts Thursday morning, but sales fell shy. The 5% revenue…
Stocks ended a choppy, high-strung session modestly lower Wednesday after seeing the Fed's post-meeting message, which held no surprises.
The S&P 500 and the Nasdaq each fell 0.3%, while the Dow Jones industrial average dipped 0.2%. Volume climbed on the Nasdaq but fell on the NYSE, according to preliminary data.

The Federal Reserve repeated its pledge to keep interest rates near zero until mid-2015 and continue buying mortgage-backed securities to spur demand for homes and support the economy's slow-but-steady growth pace.

The major averages have fallen below their 50-day lines in recent sessions after weak earnings results at bellwethers such as Google (GOOG), General Electric (GE) and McDonald's (MCD) raised concerns about the outlook for corporate profits and the economy.

Wall Street was mostly steady before the Fed's announcement, helped by better-than-expected earnings reports, bullish manufacturing data from China and higher U.S. new-home sales, although Germany's Ifo business confidence index took an unexpected drop in September.

Nationstar Mortgage Holdings (NSM) plunged 10% in massive volume, slicing then regaining its 50-day line, after the mortgage-loan servicer said it pulled out of an auction to buy loans from bankrupt lender Residential Capital, a subsidiary of government-owned lender Ally Financial. Rival Ocwen Financial (OCN) won the $3 billion bid to buy ResCap's loan-servicing unit, Bloomberg News reported, citing people familiar with the deal.
Ocwen soared 6% to a new high.

Former leader Netflix (NFLX) plunged 12% in heavy trade. The streaming movie rental operation met revenue and exceeded earnings expectations for the third quarter. But management pared its forecast for subscriber growth and pointed to rising losses from international expansion.

IAC Interactive (IACI) dived 8% in huge volume, losing support at its 50-day line, after the media company forecast an operating loss in 2013 for business units that include Newsweek magazine websites such as Ask.com. The stock had earlier fallen as much as 13%, triggering a circuit breaker that temporarily halted trading in the shares amid confusion over the company's outlook. The business segments whose outlooks were lowered represent a relatively small portion of the company's overall business.

Lumber Liquidators (LL) shot up 13% in big trade. The flooring retailer said third-quarter EPS leapt 77%, trouncing estimates of a 31% gain. Revenue also bounded past forecasts with a 19% gain. The company jacked up full-year sales and earnings guidance to well above views.
The gap-up pushed the stock 3% past a 54.10 buy point from a five-week flat base.

Mortgage-origination services provider Ellie Mae (ELLI) spiked 10% in moderately above-average volume. The stock is trying to regain its 50-day moving average. The stock cut that line of support in more than twice its average volume last week.
ResMed (RMD) jumped 3% in double its average volume, hitting a new record high after bouncing up from a test of its 10-week moving average.

The maker of devices used to treat sleep-related breathing disorders is expected to report Thursday that profit for the September-ended quarter rose 21% from a year ago, the weakest in three quarters. Sales growth has ranged from 9% to 11% over the past three quarters, well below the 25% gains that IBD-style investors like to see.
Grand Canyon Education (LOPE) rose 1% in above-average volume, ending an eight-day slide that has brought the stock through its 50-day line. Volume on the pullback has mostly been light.

The provider of post-secondary education is expected to report Nov. 1 that Q3 profit rose 17%, slowing from gains of 52% in Q1 and 21% in Q2. Revenue growth has been weak, but it's picked up for four straight quarters, from a 6% rise in Q2 last year to subsequent increases of 10%, 13%, 15% and 16%.

Monday update: Apple Inc. rose 4% Monday, rebounding from an 11-week low Friday as investors await Tuesday's likely iPad Mini unveiling and Thursday's quarterly earnings. report. Alexion Pharmaceuticals fell 3.3% Monday, extending Friday's 5.3% tumble below its 50-day moving average. Gilead Sciences edged down 0.3%. Web.com edged up 0.2%. Resmed rose 0.8%.
Apple (AAPL) earnings are hard to miss. But it's among one of 12 top-rated IBD 50 stocks that are slated to report results this week.
A barrage of earnings releases are on tap this week, many of mediocre or lagging stock. Investors need to focus on the creme de la creme of stocks.
Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN), ResMed (RMD), Web.com Group (WWWW), and Gilead Sciences (GILD) are all highly rated tech or medical firms reporting this week.

Five million people bought Apple's latest iPhone smartphone in the first three days following its debut. Still analysts thought the figure was lower than they expected. The global consumer electronics leader is holding a media event Tuesday where it's widely expected to announce a smaller, lighter and cheaper mini iPad.

Apple is slated to report fourth-quarter earnings after the market closes on Thursday. Analysts are expecting the company to post a 25% jump in EPS to $8.85. Sales are seen rising 28.2% to $36.2 billion.
Apple is ranked No. 21 on the IBD 50 list, which ranks companies based on superior earnings, strong price performance and leadership within industries.
But Apple shares have fallen hard, losing 3.2% last week — the fourth straight weekly decline.
Alexion is a biotech known for its drug Soliris, which is used for treating two rare blood diseases. It is ranked No. 4 on the IBD 50 list and is slated to report earnings on Wednesday.
The biotech is expected to report a 27% gain in EPS to 47 cents. Sales are seen jumping 43% to $293.2 million. It has posted double- or triple-digit EPS gains the last 14 quarters.
Alexion hit a record high Oct. 5 but has pulled back since. The stock fell 5.3% on Friday, closing below its 50-day line for the first time since early June.
ResMed, ranked right below Alexion on the IBD 50, makes breathing devices to help treat disorders like sleep apnea.
Analysts see its quarterly earnings jumping 31% to 46 cents when it reports earnings on Thursday. Revenue is seen rising 8.7% to $342.2 million.
ResMed shares gapped higher after the previous earnings report and continued to rise sharply until Oct. 5. The stock has since pulled back modestly.

Web.com, which provides website design and other online services for small businesses, is ranked No. 10 on the IBD 50 list. Analysts expect Q3 EPS of 39 cents, a 34% jump vs. 2011 results. EPS has risen at double-digit rates for the past eight quarters. Revenue is seen rising 164.8% to $123.54 million.
Web.com shares just closed below their 50-day line on Friday.

Gilead produces drugs to help make HIV a manageable disease. It is ranked No. 47 on the IBD 50 list. Analysts are expecting to see a 8.5% dip in earnings to 94 cents per share. Revenue is seen rising 10% to $2.34 billion.
Gilead shares have fallen about 2% in each of the past two weeks, but they remain comfortably above their 50-day line. The stock is nearly at its early October high.

Leading stocks behaved commendably as the market nosed down into correction mode and as blue chips like Chevron (CVX), Caterpillar (CAT) and  Home Depot (HD)crumbled.Nearly three-in-four IBD 50 stocks maintained support at or above their 10-week moving averages during the week. About 17 stocks in the group pulled back to test support. Nearly 20 others simply hovered stubbornly above the line.The most notable exception was Apple (AAPL) . The iPad maker slipped toward forbidden fruit territory, diving 3% for the week in heavy trade, ending 5% below its 10-week line. That left it only 11% below its Sept. 21 high. Monday's drop through the 10-week average in heavy trade, and the stock's D- Accumulation-Distribution Rating raise bright red flags.On the more positive side, DaVita (DVA) grabbed a new high in a fourth straight weekly advance. That put the dialysis clinic operator 10% above a 100.62 flat base buy point.Grand Canyon Education (LOPE) aced what was maybe a less obvious win. It rose less than 1% for the week, just enough to notch a new high and end 10% above a 21.64 buy point following a Sept. 4 breakout. More importantly, it completed a three-weeks-tight pattern and its new high sets up a buy point at 24.51. The cautions here are that the prior cup-with-handle base was dangerously V-shaped, and the Consumer Services-Education industry group ranks a weak No. 154.Stocks just easing back to their 10-week moving averages, like  NeuStar (NSR) and ResMed (RMD), could be setting the stage for rebounds. But you want to see them rise, on volume, and have the market toggled back into an uptrend before stepping in to buy.Google (GOOG) turned in its first weekly loss since the week ended July 13. It's still a long way from a test of support, but it may take a break and put together a base or at least a follow-on buy point.Cirrus Logic (CRUS), Mellanox Technologies (MLNX) and Francesca's Holdings (FRAN) were among the 10% of IBD 50 stocks that continued to lag below their 10-week moving averages. Stratasys (SSYS) made a second, valiant effort to break with that crowd and retake its 10-week line. But it didn't get the volume support it needed and managed only to end flat at the line.A few leaders, in addition to Apple, carved below their 10-week moving averages during the week. Edwards Lifesciences ' (EW) 20% plunge was the most nerve-rattling example.

Hundreds of thousands of people are expected to inherit an IRA this year. But a wrong step with an inherited IRA can be costly. IRA heirs often lose valuable tax deferral due to an unintended distribution that triggers an unwanted tax bill, notes Ed Slott, editor of the IRA Advisor newsletter. But age and marital status can give retirees special…
The Nasdaq lifted the major indexes onto mixed footing, as trade remained quiet near midday Monday.
The Nasdaq shifted from mild losses to a 0.2% gain, with Netflix's (NFLX) 5% gain leading the index.
The Dow Jones industrial average remained down 0.4% and the S&P 500 improved to a less than 0.1% loss.

The stock market today faced early pressure from a stronger dollar. A slip in the pace of existing home sales in March added to the head winds. Losses were shallow but broad, with more than 90% of the 197 industries tracked by IBD losing ground in morning trade.

Homebuilders suffered the heaviest loss, partly due to home sales data, but also because of a wide earnings miss by Virginia-based NVR (NVR). Automakers posted the biggest gain among industries, with Tesla Motors (TSLA) continuing to set the pace in that group.
At the head of the market, Halliburton (HAL) kept its 4% gain after reporting its first quarter results.
Caterpillar (CAT) managed to slip only a fraction after first-quarter results missed consensus views by a wide margin.

The two largest moves on the IBD 50 list went to drugmakers Biogen Idec (BIIB) and Celgene (CELG). Biogen jumped 4%, apparently after an analyst note detailed strong sales of the multiple sclerosis drug Tecfidera in its first week on the market. The move drove shares to a new high, 36% above the stock's most recent buy point at 155.40.
Celgene popped 3%, also stabbing to a new high. The stock is 9% past a 115.54 buy point in a three weeks tight pattern.

ResMed (RMD), a medical products maker specializing in sleep disorder treatment, jumped 3% in twice its average trade. The stock has dropped 6% below a 46.92 cup-with-handle buy point in a test of 10-week support. Stocks from the IBD 50 lineup mostly took a step back during the past week, as the major averages also retreated. The IBD 50 index fell 1.8%, while the Nasdaq lost 2%, the S&P 500 1.9% and the NYSE composite 1.5%. Worries about the fiscal cliff buffeted stocks throughout the holiday-shortened week, and the cliff remained the market's key concern…

The rules of the game may change when you hit the milestone age of 70 1/2, but the fruits of putting money into a retirement account are not out of your reach until you formally and fully retire. If you find yourself still working at this point of your life, you are probably either trying to seal a crack in your nest egg or you are one of those people who will only be ready to retire when they pry your cold dead hands from your desk. Either way, knowing you have options can make a difference in your bottom line.

In the year you turn 70 1/2, the tax system puts the lid on Traditional IRA contributions and pulls the plug on your retirement accounts in the form of required minimum distributions (RMDs). When you are earning wages and pulling out RMDs, the tax consequences can result in higher tax rates and an increased percentage of your Social Security benefits being subjected to taxes.

When your taxable income starts to bulge during that period of your life, continuing to put money into a retirement plan or Roth IRA can still be useful. Let's take a look at the major differences among the most popular retirement plan options and examine how to structure your plans to optimize your distributions.
Retirement Account Highlights
Traditional IRA
Once you turn 70 1/2, you are no longer allowed to contribute to a Traditional IRA. In addition, you must begin the process of taking annual RMDs.
Roth IRA
Anyone with earned wages may contribute to a Roth IRA, and there is no mandate requiring the contributor or his or her spouse to make RMDs.
Traditional 401(k)
Regardless of age, if you are still working you can continue to contribute to a 401(k). As long as you own less than 5% of the business you are working for, you are not required to take RMDs.
Roth 401(k)

Regardless of age, if you are still working you can contribute the full amount of your salary deferral to a Roth 401(k). Like the traditional 401(k), RMDs are required once you separate from service or if you own more than 5% of the business that employs you. This is a key difference between a Roth 401(k) and its Traditional Roth IRA counterpart.
Retirement Plan Showdowns
Traditional IRA vs. Pretax 401(k)

If you are older than 70 1/2, you lose the ability to contribute to a Traditional IRA. On the other hand, there is no age restriction placed on the 70+ crowd for contributions to a 401(k), so this option is still a possibility. In many cases, the golden-age worker is usually some kind of self-employed consultant or contractor, so these people need to be aware of the RMD requirements placed on the 5% or greater business owner. At first glance, the idea of contributing to a plan that requires you to take RMDs each year sounds silly, but if you do the math it's really not a bad deal.
Example - Pretax 401(k)

In 2011, a 75-year-old self-employed worker making $80,000 contributed $22,000 to his new 401(k); the plan has a December 31, 2011, balance of $22,000. The 2012 RMD for the now 76-year-old worker will only be $1,000. If you take the end of year balance of $22,000 and divide it by the RMD factor of a 76-year-old, 22, you end up with a taxable distribution of $1,000. After all is said and done, the net result for the individual would be a $21,000 deduction.
The point here is that the opportunity to save is not drastically diminished because you have to make RMDs while you are working.
Winner by Disqualification: Pretax 401(k)
Roth IRA vs. Roth 401(k)

If you are over 70 1/2 and you are working, you will have the ability to contribute to both types of accounts. While the income restrictions governing who can contribute to a Roth IRA can be difficult to overcome, it isn't impossible. The reason it isn't impossible involves how the income ceiling for the contribution is determined. Because the income ceiling doesn't factor into RMDs, Roth conversions and rollovers, a lot more people can qualify. On the other hand, the Roth 401(k) has no income limitations that you need to deal with. However, you need to be aware that Roth 401(k)s are eventually subject to RMDs.
Winner for Easiest Contribution Category: Roth 401(k)
Overall winner and Winner of the Final Destination Category: Roth IRA
Additional Strategies
Consolidate and Plug Your RMD Hole

It is almost a certainty that an individual working into his or her 70s will have multiple IRAs and other types of retirement plans floating around. As a result, those floating accounts will be forced to make annual RMD withdrawals. If that same individual owns less than 5% of the business he or she is working for and the plan administrator allows it, this person could roll over any existing IRAs and retirement plans into his or her current employer's plan. This is true as long as the individual has not separated from service and is still working.

Once the individual successfully rolls over the existing assets into the employer's plan, he or she should be relieved of having to take annual RMDs from those assets. The wild card in this scenario is almost always the plan document and administrator. If everything is copacetic and you are able to reduce your RMDs while you are working, you will have the opportunity to create room for doing a Roth conversion or the relief of evening out your tax burden until you fully retire.
State Income Tax "Filter"

While it depends on the state in which you live and file your taxes, some states that impose a state income tax provide more favorable tax treatment to individuals who make contributions to and take distributions from IRAs and other qualified plans. In Illinois for example, the government doesn't add your 401(k) contributions back into your state income calculation; it also allows residents to subtract most distributions from IRAs and qualified plans from income.

"State tax filter" loopholes do exist because states want to encourage their residents to stay in-state and not jump ship for no-income-tax states like Florida or Texas when they retire. That said, the loophole can be a noose if you work in a state like Pennsylvania and then retire to a state like California. In that situation, you can get taxed on the way in and the way out. How you incorporate these existing loopholes into your savings strategy will depend on your goals and your particular set of circumstances, including your CPA's advice!
Example - Taking RMDs From a Roth 401(k)

An individual who could take a look at this strategy is someone who is more than 70 years old, is self-employed and is making contributions to a Roth 401(k). In this case, if you alter your savings strategy by contributing to a pretax 401(k) and converting an outside IRA instead, you might be able to reduce your state income tax burden and avoid having to take RMDs from your Roth 401(k), which is an after-tax account.
The Bottom Line

The working crowd over 70 still has the ability to save and defer taxes through Roth IRAs and qualified plans that don't exist for their retired peers. By incorporating these and other tools into their overall strategy, the nearly retired may be able to legitimately reduce their overall tax burden to a targeted beneficiary. However, the targeted beneficiary for retirement plans isn't always the contributor, so each individual's strategy should take into account that individual's specific goals as well as the surrounding facts and circumstances. Any individual attempting to take advantage of these strategies needs to be aware that the rules surrounding their implementation are complicated and the laws can change overnight. At the end of the day, any plan incorporating these or similar types of strategies should only be executedafter receiving sound advice from a qualified tax professional in consultation with your retirement plan administrator.The rules of the game may change when you hit the milestone age of 70 1/2, but the fruits of putting money into a retirement account are not out of your reach until you formally and fully retire. If you find yourself still working at this point of your life, you are probably either trying to seal a crack in your nest egg or you are one of those people who will only be ready to retire when they pry your cold dead hands from your desk. Either way, knowing you have options can make a difference in your bottom line. In the year you turn 70 1/2, the tax system puts the lid on Traditional IRA contributions and pulls the plug on your retirement accounts in the form of required minimum distributions (RMDs). When you are earning wages and pulling out RMDs, the tax consequences can result in higher tax rates and an increased percentage of your Social Security benefits being subjected to taxes. When your taxable income starts to bulge during that period of your life, continuing to put money into a retirement plan or Roth IRA can still be useful. Your dad built up a nice IRA in his lifetime. But one wrong step by you and your siblings after his death could waste much of the balance.
Make the right moves instead, and you can add years of tax-free growth to your shares. Each of you can significantly boost the money that each of you gets.
This makes a big difference if you don't need the money right away and you'd prefer to let the account keep growing tax-deferred.
Suppose you and your two siblings, the named beneficiaries, inherit the account.
By law, you must start required minimum distributions by Dec. 31 of the year after your dad dies.
Your only alternative is to empty the account within five years. But if you don't need the money yet, that's an even bigger waste of the account's tax-free status.
Failure to abide by those two choices triggers a 50% fine.
But there are ways to cut the size of RMDs. Say that a hypothetical Al Hill died in 2011. His three children — Bob, Carol and Dan — are equal beneficiaries of his IRA.
If the heirs do nothing, RMDs will be determined by the age of the oldest beneficiary. Say that's Bob, who will be age 53 in 2012.
IRS actuarial tables say that Bob will have a life expectancy of 31.4 years. If Al Hill's IRA was worth $900,000 at the end of 2011, the RMD for 2012 would be $28,662: $900,000 divided by 31.4.
That RMD is divided three ways equally despite the age differences. Carol, age 43, and Dan, 40, must take big payouts based on Bob's shorter life expectancy. Their one-third shares are each $9,554.
This depletes the account faster than necessary .
Creating Stretch IRAs
But there is a solution. The three siblings can divide the inherited IRA into separate accounts. In this case, each would get $300,000.
"If they do this by Dec. 31, 2012, they will be able to base RMDs on their own life expectancies," said IRA expert Ed Slott.
At 43, Carol's life expectancy is 40.7 years. So her RMD would be $7,371: $300,000 divided by 40.7.
Dan's RMD would be only $6,881: his inherited $300,000 IRA divided by his 43.6-year life expectancy.
Their accounts would now be what many advisers call stretch IRAs, lasting longer than in the shared-RMD scenario.
To use individual life expectancies, all IRA beneficiaries must set up separate accounts by Dec. 31 of the year after the IRA owner's death.
Unless they all act by then, they will be locked in to higher RMDs and less wealth accumulation inside the IRA.

To separate an inherited IRA, ask the financial firm holding the IRA about its paperwork requirements, such as a copy of the IRA owner's death certificate. Beneficiaries should act well in advance of the Dec. 31 deadline to make sure transfers occur on time.
Once separate accounts have been established, beneficiaries can take the RMD or more each year.

Another deadline occurs if the list of IRA beneficiaries includes a nonindividual, say a charity or an estate. In many cases, you have to empty the inherited IRA within five years. Say Al Hill put a $60,000 bequest to his alma mater on his beneficiary form. The balance was for his three kids.
His children should instruct the IRA custodian to pay $60,000 to the college by Sept. 30 of the year after Hill's death. Then the college would not be designated under IRS rules as a beneficiary.

The three children, the designated beneficiaries, would have until the following Dec. 31, to carve the remaining $840,000 into three $280,000 inherited IRAs. Each could take RMDs over their own life expectancy.Your dad built up a nice IRA in his lifetime. But one wrong step by you and your siblings after his death could waste much of the balance.Make the right moves instead, and you can add years of tax-free growth to your shares. Each of you can significantly boost the money that each of you gets.This makes a big difference if you don't need the money right away and you'd prefer to let the account keep growing tax-deferred.Suppose you and your two siblings, the named beneficiaries, inherit the account.By law, you must start required minimum distributions by Dec. 31 of the year after your dad dies.Your only alternative is to empty the account within five years. But if you don't need the money yet, that's an even bigger waste of the account's tax-free status.Failure to abide by those two choices triggers a 50% fine.But there are ways to cut the size of RMDs. Say that a hypothetical Al Hill died in 2011. His three children — Bob, Carol and Dan — are equal beneficiaries of his IRA.If the heirs do nothing, RMDs will be determined by the age of the oldest beneficiary. Say that's Bob, who will be age 53 in 2012.IRS actuarial tables say that Bob will have a life expectancy of 31.4 years. Baby boomers planning for their retirement face unprecedented financial challenges. Unlike retirees of past generations who could rely on Social Security and employer pension plans for guaranteed income, baby boomers will likely be on their own when it comes to income generation and must rely on their savings to provide much of their retirement income. Prior to retirement, the focus is on wealth accumulation, but when retirement rolls around a fool-proof plan must be devised to ensure accumulated wealth is effectively managed to finance the entire retirement.

In this article we'll explore how traditional, safe income generating strategies may not be enough for the latest crop of retirees, and we'll look at some alternative methods to help baby boomers generate sufficient income throughout retirement.
How Much Is Enough?

With the lack in traditional sources of guaranteed retirement income, boomers find themselves with the need to turn their savings into income that lasts throughout retirement. To accomplish this goal, boomers must determine the answers to two key questions:
How Much Income Will You Need?

It would be easy to answer this question if you could see into the future to learn how long you will live, your health status for the rest of your life and how the economy and inflation will behave during your retirement. Unfortunately, there is no way to answer these questions with absolute certainty. As such, you must implement a plan based on assumptions and suppositions. Many financial planners estimate that you will need retirement income of about 75% to 100% of your pre-retirement income to maintain your pre-retirement standard of living . This, coupled with longer life expectancies, means that you will need more than previous generations to finance your retirement. For instance, In you and your spouse both retire at age 65 and need your retirement savings to pay $50,000 per year for roughly 20 years. You will need $1 million at retirement to provide sufficient income over the 20-year period.
How Can You Generate This Income?

One key step is to work with a financial planner to determine your projected retirement income needs. Social Security and pension plans used to provide a base level of retirement income that you could count on. Boomers are the first generation to see these safety nets fade away, and new creative solutions need to be found, which could include devoting more of your retirement portfolio to stocks or establishing an annuity. Another factor to consider is inflation, which can erode the purchasing power of your savings over time. Let's say you retire on an income $50,000 per year. If the rate of inflation averages only 3% per year, after 20 years, you will need $90,500 to buy what $50,000 buys today. If inflation averages 5%, the number increases to $132,500. As such, any practical financial plan for retirement must take inflation into consideration.
Implementing Your Plan

While it may be tempting to allocate all of your savings toward providing your projected retirement income needed for each year, you should designate some of your savings to cover contingencies. Throughout your lifetime, there will be circumstances, both expected and unexpected, that require funds over and above your usual income needs. Some of your savings should be earmarked to cover such expenses, so as not to stifle the flow of your regular income needs.
How to Maximize Your Income

Maximizing income from your savings will help to ensure that you are able to finance your retirement needs and wants. Contrary to popular belief, retirement is not a period where you should eliminate risk within your investments. Investing all of your savings in low-return vehicles such as money market accounts and certificates of deposit (CD) minimizes risk to principal, but there are two things to consider:
 Income from these "safe" assets may not keep pace with inflation.
 You may begin to spend principal too early during your retirement, and outlive your assets if insufficient income is generated.

Stocks have historically outpaced inflation by a significant margin and have provided the strongest return on investment over the long term, so consider keeping a portion of your savings invested in stocks and stock mutual funds throughout your retirement. Also, think about adding (or keeping) preferred stock, which almost always carries a dividend to provide income.

Investing some of your savings in an annuity may also be beneficial. Many insurance companies offer variable and equity-indexed annuities with an income rider that provides a guaranteed lifetime income withdrawal benefit and the opportunity to grow your remaining principal within the annuity. In addition, you can make withdrawals from the principal if needed.
Minimizing Risks

Investments with the potential for high returns usually have high risk of loss. If these assets, such as stocks, are included in your portfolio, it is important that you minimize the risk of losing your savings. One way to do so is to diversify your investment portfolio so that it includes a reasonable amount of growth and income producing assets to balance your investments among high-, medium- and low-risk investments. Your financial planner may recommend different strategies, depending on your investment profile.
Reducing Taxes

Taxes can eat into your income and cause your net income to be much less than anticipated. While your retirement projections must include provisions for taxes, you can take steps to reduce the amount you will owe. Here are few ideas to help minimize tax and its impact.

 Avoid putting most of your savings in low-paying fixed-interest vehicles such as money market accounts and certificates of deposit (CD), as they're not very efficient income producing investments. If you need the interest from these investments for income, you can probably get a better rate of return from other investments. Unless the investments are held in tax-deferred accounts, you will pay taxes the year the interest is earned, reducing your net earnings. Consider that the after-tax return on a CD paying 5% interest is essentially cut to 4.25% if you're in the 15% income tax bracket and 3.75% if you're in the 25% tax bracket.

 Consider an immediate annuity as an income producing alternative. Say you have $100,000 that you want to invest for income. If you invest it in a CD paying 5%, your net after-tax return is only $3,650, presuming you're in the 27% income tax bracket ($100,000 x 5% = $5,000 x 27% = $3,650). Instead, you could invest the money in an immediate annuity, which would pay you $7,545 per year for the rest of your life ($100,000 = $7,870/year - $6,666 exclusion = $1,204 taxable income x 27% income tax = $7,545 net income/year).

 Take small distributions from your individual retirement account (IRA). If you are like most people, you have two types of savings: one type that has already been taxed (after-tax money) and another that has not yet been taxed (pretax money). Some financial advisors may recommend spending your pretax money first and preserving the after-tax savings. This recommendation is usually made if you will be in your lowest tax bracket during the years the distributions occur; however, if the bulk of your saving will be spent during the earlier years of your retirement, it may make sense to withdraw the after-tax amounts during those periods so as to reduce the tax impact. In other cases, a financial advisor may recommend that you withdraw a little from each. The key is to ensure that your withdrawal strategy is one that will result in the lowest possible tax liability.

 Consider converting some of your Traditional IRA assets to a Roth IRA if you are eligible to do so. Earnings on Roth IRA assets are tax-free if qualified, and there is no required minimum distribution (RMD) amounts.
Example: Traditional IRA vs. Roth IRA
Suppose you own a $300,000 Traditional IRA and you also have $90,000 in regular savings. Let's assume everything grows at exactly 10% per year, and your tax bracket is at the 30% rate.

 The Traditional IRA will generate income in the amount of $30,000 annually. The income tax due on that distribution would be roughly $9,000, resulting in net income of $21,000. The savings also generate 10% income, or $9,000 per year. After taxes, the net income is $6,300. So the total annual net income will be $27,300 from these accounts.

 If the $300,000 were converted to a Roth IRA, the tax owed would be about $90,000 or the value of the entire savings account for the year the conversion occurs. However, the $30,000 income from the Roth IRA would be income tax free.
Thus, the $300,000 Roth IRA generates $30,000 net income while the $300,000 Traditional IRA coupled with an additional $90,000 from savings provides an income, net after taxes, of $27,300.
The Bottom Line

If you are like most people, you have two types of savings: one type that has already been taxed (after-tax money) and another that has not yet been taxed (pretax money). Some financial advisors may recommend spending your pretax money first and preserving the after-tax savings. This recommendation is usually made if you will be in your lowest tax bracket during the years the distributions occur; however, if the bulk of your saving will be spent during the earlier years of your retirement, it may make sense to withdraw the after-tax amounts during those periods so as to reduce the tax impact. In other cases, a financial advisor may recommend that you withdraw a little from each. The key is to ensure that your withdrawal strategy is one that will result in the lowest possible tax liability. Consider converting some of your Traditional IRA assets to a Roth IRA if you are eligible to do so. Earnings on Roth IRA assets are tax-free if qualified, and there is no required minimum distribution (RMD) amounts. Example: Traditional IRA vs. Roth IRA Suppose you own a $300,000 Traditional IRA and you also have $90,000 in regular savings. Let's assume everything grows at exactly 10% per year, and your tax bracket is at the 30% rate.  The Traditional IRA will generate income in the amount of $30,000 annually. The income tax due on that distribution would be roughly $9,000, resulting in net income of $21,000. The savings also generate 10% income, or $9,000 per year. After taxes, the net income is $6,300. So the total annual net income will be $27,300 from these accounts. If the $300,000 were converted to a Roth IRA, the tax owed would be about $90,000 or the value of the entire savings account for the year the conversion occurs. However, the $30,000 income from the Roth IRA would be income tax free. Thus, the $300,000 Roth IRA generates $30,000 net income while the $300,000 Traditional IRA coupled with an additional $90,000 from savings provides an income, net after taxes, of $27,300.  The Bottom LineBaby boomers planning for retirement will be confronted with financial challenges that are much different than those of their predecessors. With the shift from defined-benefit plans to defined-contribution plans, and the uncertain future of social security, boomers are on their own when it comes to financing retirement. As such, they must generate more of the income they will need in retirement from their own savings. Additionally, with the increase in life expectancy, assets used to finance retirement will need to last longer than ever before. Finding ways to minimize expenses, preserve savings, account for inflation and reduce taxes is of paramount importance for this new generation of retirees.

Less than half of workers making $100,000 or more a year believe they save enough for retirement. That's what a recent Edward Jones survey found. If you're among those undersavers, you can do something about it. And it's worthwhile. Even a small increase can add big bucks to your balance over time. How? Through the power of compounding interest. It…

Social Security benefits — yours, your parents or an elderly relative's, let's say — can be subject to income tax. But you can take steps to minimize or avoid the hit, which can save thousands of dollars. The key is to trim your non-Social Security income — often by turning vulnerable categories of income into safe ones. Suppose a hypothetical…

Tax-deferred retirement accounts shield income from tax as long as the money stays put. But even if you don't need the money, you must take out at least a certain amount each year after you reach age 70 1/2. Required minimum distributions (RMDs) apply to most plans. That includes traditional IRAs, SIMPLE IRAs and SEP IRAs. If you still have…

Japan. Haiti. Every year seems to bring a big natural disaster. In response, Americans typically like to help victims. That's in addition to the local charitable donations people routinely make. You can contribute by writing a check. After you reach age 70 1/2, you have an additional choice. At that age, you can donate directly from your IRA. The limit…
When the paychecks stop coming, you'd like your portfolio to start producing retirement income.
How should you go about it?
"For many people, it makes sense to start by taking money from your taxable accounts," said Christine Fahlund, senior financial planner at T. Rowe Price.
This lets your traditional individual retirement account continue to rack up tax-deferred earnings.

If you have a Roth IRA, its earnings and withdrawals can eventually be tax-free. Taking money from taxable accounts is especially vital before 59 1/2. Reaching that age is part of what makes Roth IRA earnings and withdrawals tax-free.
Ticktock To 59 1/2
Before that age, withdrawals from a traditional IRA will be hit with a 10% penalty unless you qualify for an exemption. Even penalty-free, you'll owe regular income tax.
Once you pass 59 1/2, you'll have more flexibility. One option is to tap your traditional IRA to fill up a low tax bracket, Fahlund says.
Say a hypothetical Cal and Lucy Morgan are retirees in their 60s. They expect their taxable income to be $65,000 this year.

In 2011, married couples filing a joint return with up to $69,000 of taxable income are in the 15% federal income tax bracket. So Cal Morgan can take $4,000 from his traditional IRA for spending money and still be in the 15% bracket.
Once you reach age 70 1/2, required minimum distributions from your traditional IRAs begin. You can tap your taxable accounts for additional funds, if needed.
Say a Pam Collins is 71. She expects to need $60,000 to cover her expenses this year. Based on her age and IRA balance, her RMD this year is $22,000. She will also get $25,000 from Social Security.
She should pull the remaining $13,000 from her taxable account.

Where to withdraw from is not your only decision. You must also choose what to withdraw. One strategy is to start with investment income in your taxable account. Paying tax on it, you might as well spend that dividend and interest income. But low interest rates now can curb your interest and dividends. You can sell securities for cash. What should you sell? One approach is to rebalance your portfolio, selling what has done the best.
Suppose a Bob Williams is 65. He has $500,000 in a traditional IRA and $500,000 in a taxable account.

Williams wants $40,000 for spending money this year. His taxable account generates $14,000 in taxable interest and dividends. He needs to tap his portfolio for an additional $26,000. So he checks his assets to find an excess allocation.

Williams' existing game plan calls for a 10% weight in U.S. midcaps.That would be $100,000. Now he has $150,000 in midcap stocks and funds. So that allocation is $50,000 over his target. If he sells $50,000 worth of midcaps in his taxable account, he will be on track. He can use $26,000 of the sales proceeds as spending money.
Freedom

Williams can invest the other $24,000 of proceeds any way he'd like. One option: Put the money into asset classes that are below his ideal allocation. The downside is that selling winners in a taxable account will produce taxable gains. That problem can be reduced if Williams tells his broker or fund company to sell the highest-cost lots.

Taking some gains inside an IRA is another way to trim taxes. As long as Williams keeps the money inside his IRA and uses it to rebalance, he won't owe tax. One more option is to take offsetting capital losses in your taxable account to cut or eliminate net capital gains.When the paychecks stop coming, you'd like your portfolio to start producing retirement income.How should you go about it?"For many people, it makes sense to start by taking money from your taxable accounts," said Christine Fahlund, senior financial planner at T.
